awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: SWIFT: LARGE: Dynamics and Security Aware Predictive Spectrum Sharing with Active and Passive Users
awd_abstract_narration:
This project is helping to lay the foundation for more efficient and secure access to wireless spectrum while protecting essential existing uses of that spectrum.  This access is critical to meet the demands from both legacy and emerging wireless applications, that have potential benefits across society.  To this end, we are developing novel sensors, algorithmic solutions, models and architecture for future Data-Aware Spectrum Access Systems (DASASs) that will extend the current state-of-the-art to enable date driven solutions for spectrum access.  Other impacts of this project include outreach to K-12 education, training and mentoring students including undergraduates and under-represented minorities, and developing new courses related to the proposed research.

The envisioned system will leverage extensive low-cost sensing to support spectrum sharing across different frequency bands at different timescales for a rich set of different use cases including static and mobile users, active and passive spectrum utilization, and planned versus random uses.   We  are taking a multidisciplinary approach to design this system including: developing low cost spectrum sensors that utilize novel low-power distributed algorithms; understanding how to efficiently integrate and query the data obtained from these algorithms with other sources (e.g., weather, spatial density of demands) and use it to predictively trigger  algorithms for spectrum allocation decisions; developing new and scalable spectrum allocation algorithms that use the acquired data to manage a wide range of users of the spectrum while accounting for market competition; and ensuring that the resulting system can leverage the available data to be secure against malicious attackers and unintentional user behavior.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: IOWA STATE UNIVERSITY OF SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY

por.por_cntn:
The project aimed to lay the foundation for more efficient and secure access to wireless spectrum while protecting essential existing uses of that spectrum. This is critical to meet the demands from both legacy and emerging wireless applications, that have potential benefits across society. We developed novel sensors, algorithmic solutions, models and architecture for future Data-Aware Spectrum Access Systems (DASASs) to extend the current state-of-the-art to enable date driven solutions for spectrum access. Other impacts of this project include outreach to K-12 education, training and mentoring students including undergraduates and under-represented minorities, and development of new courses related to the research topics.

This is a collaborative project between Northwestern University and Iowa State University (ISU), funded as part of the NSF SWIFT program. The ISU team was in charge of two thrusts: (1) spatio-temporal data management and deep learning models for recommendations and predictions in mobility settings; (2) information security and privacy aspects. Following is the summary of the main outcomes from the ISU team.

(1)            Spatio-temporal data and phenomena - we generated efficient and effective solutions to problems related to: (i)  Overcoming the challenges of the existing machine learning and neural network-based models for IP geolocation. We tackled cases of sparse data and explicitly incorporated the uncertainty in the model, thus adding robustness (in terms of adaptability to noises) of the geo-location estimate. (ii) Estimating the density fluctuations in urban settings. We addressed the problem of Fine-grained Urban Flow Inference (FUFI), upscaling the coarse-grained, low-resolution urban flow map into fine-grained, high-resolution ones. FUFI is useful in large-scale urban transportation systems, e.g., citywide traffic flow monitoring and radio map reconstruction. (iii) Detection of fake and anomalous trajectories - we tackled the, so called “Open World” settings, in which not every trajectory is known during the training. (iv) We provided a novel solutions to the problem of link prediction in evolving heterogeneous networks. We proposed an approach to overcome the constraint of discrete time-instants and tackled the settings of continuous time model for dynamic graph learning, as well as prediction in both transductive and inductive settings. (v) Human mobility prediction – i.e., learning human behavioral patterns and individual preferences from massive spatial-temporal trajectory data. We overcame the problems of the existing works concentrating on fusing different semantics underlying sequential trajectories for mobility pattern learning which yields a narrow perspective on comprehending human intrinsic motions. We also addressed the inherent sparsity and under-explored heterogeneous collaborative items pertaining to human check-ins, which can hinder the exploitation of human diverse periodic regularities and common interests.

(2)            Security and privacy: (i) We provided novel meaningful measures of information leakage with incomplete information (on privacy mechanism and original data), and we extended it towards developing novel reusable authentication schemes, coupling user’s biometric and device footprint. We developed a novel algorithm for co-location based key establishment, which is robust against active attackers, introducing a formulated optimization problems for each of these diverse adversaries. The solution to these optimization problems results in an optimized information disclosure mechanism that will minimize the worst-case maximization of any of the proposed metrics. (ii) We established an automatic key protocol between the two legitimate parties who enjoy more quality time with each other than the attacker and applies a set intersection method and erasure coding. We also targeted the challenges of existing Android program analysis tools and proposed an online-offline approach to solve them via precisely and completely summarizing data-flow information inside the Android native libraries. (iii) We addressed the issue of efficiency of mobile apps forensic analyses in the context of fuzzing tools. Given that mobile apps can generate more than 19,000 files on a single device, it is time consuming and error prone to manually inspect all the files. Fuzzing tools that programmatically produce interactions with mobile apps are helpful when paired with sandbox environments to study their runtime forensic behavior and summarize patterns of evidentiary data in forensic investigations. (iv) We provided a quantitative demonstration for the simplest, binary scenario, showing how to find an optimized privacy mechanism that minimizes the worst-case value of average subjective leakage, average confidence boost, and average objective leakage.

Five PhD students were partially supported at the Dept. of Electrical and Computer Engineering at ISU, three of whom have graduated (two joined industry (Google and Esri) and one is an Assistant Professor at Univ. of Tennessee at Chattanooga).and one.  The project provided training opportunities for two MS students and multiple undergraduate students via Senior Design projects and Honor Mentoring program – leading to 12 undergraduates co-authoring conference papers.

The main findings were published in conference papers and journal articles (posted on NSF PAR). The project webpage (https://sites.northwestern.edu/sharedspectrum/) contains summary of the objectives, accomplishments and activities from the collaborative NSF funded proposals.

 


Last Modified: 04/17/2025
Modified by: Goce P Trajcevski

This is critical to meet the demands from both legacy and emerging wireless applications, that have potential benefits across society. We developed novel sensors, algorithmic solutions, models and architecture for future Data-Aware Spectrum Access Systems (DASASs) to extend the current state-of-the-art to enable date driven solutions for spectrum access. Other impacts of this project include outreach to K-12 education, training and mentoring students including undergraduates and under-represented minorities, and development of new courses related to the research topics.


This is a collaborative project between Northwestern University and Iowa State University (ISU), funded as part of the NSF SWIFT program. The ISU team was in charge of two thrusts: (1) spatio-temporal data management and deep learning models for recommendations and predictions in mobility settings; (2) information security and privacy aspects. Following is the summary of the main outcomes from the ISU team.


(1) Spatio-temporal data and phenomena - we generated efficient and effective solutions to problems related to: (i) Overcoming the challenges of the existing machine learning and neural network-based models for IP geolocation. We tackled cases of sparse data and explicitly incorporated the uncertainty in the model, thus adding robustness (in terms of adaptability to noises) of the geo-location estimate. We addressed the problem of Fine-grained Urban Flow Inference (FUFI), upscaling the coarse-grained, low-resolution urban flow map into fine-grained, high-resolution ones. (2) Security and privacy: (i) We provided novel meaningful measures of information leakage with incomplete information (on privacy mechanism and original data), and we extended it towards developing novel reusable authentication schemes, coupling users biometric and device footprint. (iv) We provided a quantitative demonstration for the simplest, binary scenario, showing how to find an optimized privacy mechanism that minimizes the worst-case value of average subjective leakage,average confidence boost, andaverage objective leakage.


Five PhD students were partially supported at the Dept. of Electrical and Computer Engineering at ISU, three of whom have graduated (two joined industry (Google and Esri) and one is an Assistant Professor at Univ. of Tennessee at Chattanooga).and one. The project provided training opportunities for two MS students and multiple undergraduate students via Senior Design projects and Honor Mentoring program  leading to 12 undergraduates co-authoring conference papers.


The main findings were published in conference papers and journal articles (posted on NSF PAR). The project webpage (https://sites.northwestern.edu/sharedspectrum/) contains summary of the objectives, accomplishments and activities from the collaborative NSF funded proposals.
